subject: Re: [junit] Testing Connection Pools
msgSnippet: ... This is what I was looking for - I already call con.commit(). (After checking if commit() is supported, of course.) Any ideas? ... -- *   Jim Cheesman   *
messageBody:
At 12:39 PM 22/06/01, you wrote:
>Does this technique handle mean that developers that forget to close()
>ResultSets and PreparedStatements won't cause problems? Do you have any
>idea if this true for all JDBC implementations (with the appropriate check)?


This is what I was looking for - I already call con.commit(). (After
checking if commit() is supported, of course.)

Any ideas?



>----- Original Message -----
>From: "David Roussel" <dir@...>
>To: <junit@yahoogroups.com>
>Sent: Friday, June 22, 2001 5:10 AM
>Subject: RE: [junit] Testing Connection Pools
>
>
> > I don't know which connection pool you on about but I know how my own
> > connection pool works. When a connection is returned it checks the
> > transaction and rolls it back it one is open "SELECT @@trancount" on SQL
> > Server. This also serves the purpose of making sure the connection is OK,
> > i.e. no network cables pulled out etc. If the connection is working then
> > its put back in the pool. If the connection is faulty then it is closed
>and
> > removed from the pool.
> >
> > Not sure how you make sure all connections are returned. Could do with a
> > way to signal all sub-systems to return any connections and then check
>that
> > none are still checked out of the pool.
> >
> > Dave
> >
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: Jim Cheesman [mailto:jchees@...]
> > Sent: 22 June 2001 09:58
> > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > Subject: RE: [junit] Testing Connection Pools
> >
> >
> >
> > >For software quality two of the most important things to test for
> > >(if you can) are:
> > >1. Connections are 'clean' when you put them back in the pool.
> > >The next piece of code to use the connection should be able to
> > >do so without fear of picking up a bad connection or one which
> > >wasn't tidied up properly by the last user.
> >
> > Just out of interest, (and getting a little OT) is there any way to check
> > (within the code - not as a unit test) that the connection is "clean" - ie
> > ResultSets, statements closed etc.?
> >
> >
> >
> > Jim
